key_patterns_identified.description: Northeast monsoon (October-March) brings cold surges that cause 30-40% increases in PM2.5 through long-range transport from China and local pollution stagnation
Urban PM2.5 shows morning peak (7-8 AM, traffic) and evening peak (7-11 PM, boundary layer collapse + traffic), with minimum around noon
Rice straw burning in June and October causes significant PM2.5 spikes, contributing 14-18% of Vietnam's total PM2.5 emissions
Dry season (January-May) biomass burning in SEA contributes up to 45-68% of PM2.5 in border regions, peaking in March
New Year/Tet fireworks cause acute PM2.5 spikes up to 383.9 µg/m³ with 5.7x enrichment in particle mass

data_quality_notes: All sources are Tier-1 peer-reviewed journals
Most findings have high confidence based on quantitative measurements
Some relationships extrapolated from China studies to Vietnam context
Temporal coverage spans 2002-2024, providing long-term perspective
